container-title: She is the author of Deconstruction and Translation, and is currently working on the book project Unbirthing the Nation: The Middle Ages and Postcolonial Time
title: Kathleen Davis is assistant professor of English at Princeton University. Her essays have addressed issues of gender and translation, particularly as they relate to medieval national discourse

note: Psychoanalysis, Historicism, Chaucer (Minnesota, 2002) and City, Marriage, Tournament: Arts of Rule in Late Medieval Scotland.
title: Aranye Fradenburg is professor of English, women’s studies, and comparative literature at the University of California, Santa Barbara. She is the author of Sacrifice Your Love
She has also written on medieval, early modern, and contemporary poetry, drama, narrative, and film

container-title: Geography, and English Identity in the Middle Ages
title: Kathy Lavezzo teaches English at the University of Iowa. She is completing a book, Angels on the Edge of the World: Literature

Larry Scanlon is associate professor of English at Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey. He is editor of Studies in the Age of Chaucer and is currently finishing a book on sexual regulation, medieval writing, and postmodern theory

container-title: His books include The Book of the Incipit: Beginnings in the Fourteenth Century (Minnesota, 2001) and Arts of Possession: The Middle English Household Imaginary
title: Vance Smith is associate professor of English and Jonathan Dickinson Bicentennial Preceptor at Princeton University

Claire Sponsler teaches English at the University of Iowa. She is author of Drama and Resistance: Bodies, Goods, and Theatricality in Late Medieval England (Minnesota, 1997) and coeditor of East of West: Cross-cultural Performance and the Staging of Difference
